6a9299b5-7ec9-40e8-955d-408344e7ea2e.content:

- netmiko_check_vrf_test - DEVICE Washington : Using cached Netmiko connection
- netmiko_check_vrf_test - DEVICE Washington : Closed netmiko connection

735baaec-e1f2-4b17-b402-11d8ae7a0d75.content:
This workflow tests:
- the targets defined as a combination of devices and pools.
It runs on two devices, the pool "Washington" and the device "Austin".
- The netmiko Validation and Configuration services. It creates and
deletes a VRF on the router with Netmiko.
- The connection cache management: closing cached connection,
opening new connection, reusing cached connection.
At the end of the workflow, the cache connection should be closed.
Expected log:
- Regression Workflow 4: VRF creation and deletion with Netmiko -
DEVICE Washington : Closed netmiko connection

a7458a18-4812-498e-857d-b885237a6525.content:
This service is configured with "Start New Connection".
It should close the connection opened at the previous service,
and start a new one.
Expected Log:
- Netmiko: Check VRF (test) does not exist - DEVICE Washington : Closed netmiko connection
- Netmiko: Check VRF (test) does not exist - DEVICE Washington : Opening new Netmiko connection

b5dc9b96-d0bf-4092-8e60-b82ca6db2ad6.content:
This service should automatically detect that there is no
longer a cached connection, and recreate a new one.
Expected log:
netmiko_delete_vrf_test - DEVICE Washington : Opening new Netmiko connection

1dff7d24-0b6b-4524-a07a-26ac67e1ae2c.content:
Uses Ansible to do a "show configuration":
  tasks:
    - name: eos show commands
      eos_command:
        commands:
          - show running-config
        provider: "{{ cli }}"
      register: output
Convert the result to text and check that the result matches
the following regular expression: "ip address\s.*/32"

36072c59-543f-4600-b2be-f88c366ccb79.content:
Uses Ansible to do a "show configuration".
Convert the result to a dictionary and check that it
contains the following dictionary:
{"action":"debug","changed":false,"failed":false}

813cd109-d252-4731-99b8-7a0828883b6d.content:
Uses Ansible to do a "show version":
  tasks:
    - name: eos show commands
      eos_command:
        commands:
          - show version
        provider: "{{ cli }}"
      register: output

Converts the results to a dictionary.
Check that the results contains the following dictionary:
{"ok": 2} (via dictionary inclusion)

0d15f57d-aef4-47a4-9ba5-86ab26acace4.content:
This service tests the case where both iteration devices and iteration values
are used at the same time.
The first service sets the necessary variables, and the next 3 services uses
the iteration value with netmiko to run a "show interface {{ value }}" command.
The last service uses the iteration value to make a REST call to the following URL:
http://127.0.0.1:5000/rest/instance/device/{{iteration_value}}

5043ff9c-79b0-4712-a706-502724ac4e31.content:
The iteration devices field is set to "get_var("Derived Devices", device=device.name)"
The iteration values are set to ["Loopback11","Loopback15"] (static), and the name
of the iteration variable is set to a non-default value.
The service does a "show interface" over the loopback interfaces.
For "Austin", one of the iterated device is "Dummy1" which does not exist,
so netmiko should fail to connect and the service will fail for Dummy1.
Austin should stop here as a result, while Washington moves forward.

76ece5f4-54f7-4f6b-8ea0-7d2918524e92.content:
Only Washington should reach this service.
This service iterates over a set of values "Interfaces 1"
defined at the first step ("Modify Payload"):
get_var('Interfaces 1', device=device.name)
The "get_var" function will evaluate to
['Loopback101', 'Loopback15']. None of these interfaces
exist, and the validation checks for "does not exist" in the
output, so the service should pass.

93d396cb-cc7e-47ac-ac12-8f75207dcb14.content:
This service combines iteration devices and iteration values once again.
The iteration devices query is the same as  in "Test 1", except that it uses
the "parent_device" global variable in the get_var function.
When iteration devices are computed, "parent_device" and "device"
should evaluate to the same device.
For each derived device, it will iterate over the "Interface 2" variable which will
evaluate to ['Loopback333', 'Loopback334'] (set in the Modify Payload service).
The validation checks that "does not exist" is in the result.

b61a926f-87e4-48a6-86bd-74500e9568ab.content:
Set the following variables in the payload :
- Interfaces 1 : ['Loopback101', 'Loopback15'] for "Washington"
otherwise ['Loopback9', 'Loopback1000']
- Derived Devices : ["Dummy1", "Austin"] for "Austin" else ["Washington"]
- Interfaces 2 : ['Loopback333', 'Loopback334'] for any device

fbd0224f-eae2-461b-bfc5-9de385e078f0.content:
The iteration values field is hardcoded to '["Washington", "Atlanta"]'.
The service makes a REST call to
http://127.0.0.1:5000/rest/instance/device/{{get_var('iteration_value')}}.

This workflow tests:
- subworkflow iteration (to run both in device by device and service by service mode)
- having the same shared service in different subworkflow (make sure the progress
is displayed per subworkflow and not for the whole runtime)

468e9cf3-85da-4e97-9a1c-0acc89076aeb.content:
This first subworkflow will run on Washington and Minneapolis
as hardcoded iterated devices.
Washington should pass the shared service, Minneapolis fail.
A failure edge is drawn to the end, so both iterated devices
should pass the workflow, and it should be a success
for PaloAlto (iteration device).

77bbb8a5-d4ab-4eed-818d-da17f6ec405d.content:
This subworkflow contains the same shared service, but :
- it runs on Washington and Dummy1
- Dummy1 should fail and no failure edge exists to the end
=> The workflow should fail for PaloAlto.
PaloAlto should still reach end through the failure edge,
so the top-level workflow should be a success.

This workflow tests the skip mechanism in SxS with WF targets mode.
It runs on three devices: Austin, PaloAlto, Washington. Washington will
fail at the first service and stop.
The second service aims at making sure that a service that is skipped globally
should not prevent devices from moving forward throughout the workflow.

devices to move forward: the third service will skip PaloAlto with the skip
query, set to a skip value of False. PaloAlto should go to the end via the
failure edge, and Austin via the success edge.

16752478-6639-43a8-a2c5-e5dedd826184.content:
This workflow must be tested with all different types of credential: 
- Credential type "any" (default) should work as described on the left:
3 pass, 1 fail (Austin-3).
- Credential type "read-only": Washington should fail with the exception
"No matching credentials found", because its associated credential
is set to read-write.
However, Austin3 should pass along with Austin and Austin-2
because the Austin-3 "wrong credentials" is also set to read-write,
so Austin-3 will use the right credential (SSH key) even though
it has lower priority.
- Credential type "read-write": Austin and Austin-2 should use the
password-based credential instead of the key-based credential
because it is set to read-only.
Austin-3 should use the wrong credentials and fail.

86737c37-94b1-4c51-8f57-9cfcd32caf5a.content:
This workflow runs on Washington, Austin, Austin-2 and Austin-3.

- Washington will use "Router Credentials - Password" (correct credentials).
- Austin and Austin-2 will match both "Router Credentials - Password"
and "Router Credentials - SSH Key", but the SSH key has higher priority
so they should use that to log in.
- Austin-3 will match all credentials but "Router Credentials - Wrong Password"
has higher priority, so it should be used and
the connection should fail.

All devices but Austin-3 should pass. For Austin and Austin-2,
the authentication in the server logs should say "authentication (publickey)"
and for Washington, "authentication (keyboard-interactive)".
The logs also indicate which credentials were used.

f721f743-3dd8-40a2-a5eb-5680a80b50da.content:
This workflow is configured in SxS with device targets mode.
When a service fails, there can be a remediation process to apply to
the failed devices before moving on to the next service.
The remediation branch must be run before the next service if there are any
failed device, while not preventing the workflow from running to
completion if there aren't any.
This justifies the move from the concept of "prerequisite edges" to a
priority-based graph traversal implemented with Dijkstra algorithm.
The remediation branch (Failure Case, Remediation) has a higher priority
than the "Last Service", so the devices that fail "Dispatch Devices" will run
the remediation branch first, then all devices will run "Last Service" together.
In DxD run mode, there would not be a need for any of this.

We set "results["result"]" to {"a": {"b": "LOL"}}.
We then check, via String Inclusion Validation,
that "OL" is included in "results['result']["a"]["b"]".

82b58ac0-c894-4f7f-9b8c-1b4399c3cb2d.content:
By default, the validation mechanism takes place on the
"result" key of the results ("results['result']"). The "Section to Validate"
field lets you change that default behavior.
* The first service uses the default behavior of checking against
"results['result']".
* The second service uses dictionary inclusion validation against
a new top level key of the result dictionary.
* The third service uses string inclusion validation against
an inner key of results['result'].

That extracted information is stored both in the workflow payload and the results of the extraction
service :
- the left side of the workflow uses the "get_result" method to retrieve the results and validate them.
- the right side uses "get_var" to extract data from the payload and validate it.

the left side (validate via result) and the right side (validate via payload) to check that
an older payload / result can be retrieved from the database.

c23ca0ee-235d-404a-bc08-fe900792803a.content:
This workflows tests the Gateway feature: we connect to a remote network device via a Gateway device, called "Gateway".
The workflow runs in Service Targets mode, with two Netmiko Validation services :
- the first tests the gateway mechanism in case there is one, reachable gateway. It has one target, "Router behind Gateway 1"
whose "gateways" field is set to "Gateway 1". 
- the second service tests the priority tie break mechanism: eNMS tries the gateways,
from the highest to the lowest priority until one is reachable.
It has one target: "Router behind Gateway 1, 2 and 3".
Gateway 3 has the highest priority, it should be selected but is unreachable (wrong IP).
It should then try Gateway 2 (higher priority than Gateway 1, also unreachable) and finally fall back on Gateway 1.
- the last service runs on both "Router behind Gateway 1" and "Router behind Gateway 1, 2 and 3".
The behavior should be the same as that of the first and second services:
* Gateway 1 should be used right away "Router behind Gateway 1"
* Gateway 1 should be used as a fall back after trying Gateway 2 and 3 for "Router behind Gateway 1, 2 and 3"

Runs on "Router behind Gateway 1, 2 and 3".
Should try and fail connecting to Gateway 3,
then Gateway 2, and finally succeed connecting
to Gateway 1.
Two stacktraces expected in the logs.

4a30f572-f837-428f-9f47-52f012b79779.content:
We will now update the parameterized form by removing its properties
one by one, and check that as soon as a property is removed, its counterpart
in the parent workflow is used instead.
5) Edit the workflow to remove the "device_query" property from the
parameterized form.
Now that it is no longer defined in the form, the value of device query should
 come from the workflow, where it is set to ["Atlanta"].
6) Run the workflow with empty parameterized form and check that the
workflow now runs on Atlanta.
7) Run the workflow with devices set to ["Jackson", "PaloAlto"] and check
that the workflow runs on Atlanta, PaloAlto and Jackson.
8) Edit the workflow to remove the "target_devices" property
9) Run the workflow with empty parameterized form and check that it now
runs on Austin and Atlanta.
10) Edit the workflow to have no parameterized properties.
11) Run the workflow with empty parameterized form, and check that it
 runs on the original workflow targets: Austin, Washington and Atlanta.

4eaef783-740b-4b1a-973b-657d2fe0b42a.content:
The parameterized form contains all target related properties:
"target_devices", "target_pools", "device_query"
and "device_query_property".
As soon as one of these "target properties" is detected by eNMS
 in the parameterized form, it takes precedence over what is defined
in the parent workflow.
The parent workflow is configured to run on Austin (devices),
Washington (pools) and Atlanta (device query).
1) Run the workflow without parameterized form: it should run
on Austin, Washington and Atlanta.
2) Run the workflow with parameterized form without setting
any targets: it should abort with the "No targets defined" message.
 3) Run the workflow with one parameterized device: check that only
that one device is used as a target.
4) Run the workflow with "Washington" as parameterized pool and
"Boston" as parameterized device query: check that only these two
devices are used as targets.

0e40b23e-b930-425f-907c-7060bd12a8d2.content:
The payload of a run is saved in the Run.payload row.
A large payload can impact the performances of various endpoints,
including the workflow builder refresh mechanism (via the
controller.get_service_state function) and the "Results" page in the
menu, because the payload is loaded when runs are fetched from the
database.
To avoid these issues, deferred column loading is used.
This workflow artificially creates a very large payload to assess the
impact on the performances.
The workflow runs in DxD mode on 10 devices.
The "Create Large Payload" saves 1M characters in the payload,
for each device.
It must be run at least 5 times before testing the UI.

The "success" value is computed with the 
following check:
"boot system flash" in previous_result

356d7962-969b-463b-9579-ca54dbbe8c1e.content:
Send "show run" command.
"Dry Run" is checked by default.

For the second test, it must be unchecked.

cdec1722-5f82-4f64-8ffc-c6701773bb61.content:
This workflow should be run twice:
- a first time as-is, with "Show Configuration" in "Dry Run" mode
- a second time with "Dry Run" unchecked on that same service

It has two targets: "Washington" (real router) and "Router1" (fake router).

- In the case of a dry run, the "results" of "Show Configuration" are modified to
include the output of the "show configuration" command as if it had successfully
connected to the device. The "result" key should then contain the configuration,
and it will be used by the python snippet service that comes next to very that the
string ""boot system flash" is present in the configuration. The "success" value of
that service depends on that check.
Both routers should pass.

- In the case of a real run (the "Dry Run" checkbox of the first service must be
unchecked), "Router 1" should fail at the first service (no connection can be
established), and "Washington" should pass both services.

In Step 2: try_set(device, "operating_system", "TEST")
Then check in postprocessing that the value was set:
results["success"] = device.operating_system == "TEST"

67c325f3-39fe-4c08-bdde-41cc1f1dafcc.content:
This workflow tests 3 global variables:
- "try_set": used to set an object property to a given value and try to commit (with retries)
- "try_commit": takes a transaction function as input along with its parameters
  (*args, **kwargs), and try to commit (with retries)
- "get_secret": used to get the value of a Secret object. The user running the
  workflow must have "Use" acccess to the Secret object to obtain the value.

The workflow should be run by two users:
- admin: runs to completion
- nadmin: fails at the last service, because while nadmin does have Read and
Edit access to "Secret 1", it does not have the "Use" access to obtain the value.

9714b1cb-69e7-412c-a4b7-87370f86423e.content:
In Step 2:

result = get_secret("Secret 1")
results["result"] = result

Then check in postprocessing that the value was set:
results["result"] == "Correct123!:)$@"

d292439f-35b7-4c11-8a77-a3c5d3cfcac0.content:
In Step 2:

def transaction(device):
    device.operating_system = ""
try_commit(transaction, device)

Then check in postprocessing that the value was set:
results["success"] = device.operating_system == ""

5ff90d7c-7382-4e15-8105-85e3448f9ad6.content:
This workflow tests:
- The ordering mechanism of a instance or multiple instance field: by using the "order"
key, a user should be defined to choose a property by which the instance should be
ordered, as well as a direction ("asc" or "desc")
- The available of a global "user" variable set to the current user. Typically, by filtering
the "run" list based on on the "creator" column set to "user.name", we ensure that the
user running the workflow will only have access to its own previous runs.
- Users can select a run from the parameterized form, then convert the run ID to an
actual run object (because the global run property coming from the form will be set
to the selected run ID)
- The ability for the "get_result" function to retrieve results from previous runs via the
"runtime" keyword argument (and not just for the on-going run)

b17aecda-1373-47cc-aaf4-404950308d74.content:
3) Run the workflow again, this time by selecting any device AND
the previous run. This time, it should work because we use the "runtime"
keyword argument of "get_result" to fetch the result from the previous
run, based on the runtime of the run object.

b3ca710e-efe4-4e0c-9b21-84534d3e9ca7.content:
run_object = fetch("run", id=old_run, allow_none=True)
if run_object:
    results["success"] = run_object.runtime == get_result(
        "Parameterized Column Ordering and Global user Property",
        runtime=run_object.runtime)["runtime"]
else:
    results["success"] = False

5c7d0c38-a8af-46cc-a843-6b02e60bf110.content:
This workflow runs in DxD on a single device. It has a preprocessing section where:
- a "property_two" variable is set to "ip_address".
- a "model" variable is set to "device"
- a "payload_dict" variable is set to {"columns": ["name", "model", "vendor"], "maximum_return_records": 5, "start": 0, "type": "device"}
The first service, Dict Substitution, uses the following payload:
{"columns": ["name", "{{ property_two }}", "maximum_return_records": 3,
"start": 0, "type": "{{ get_var('model') }}"}
It must be converted to a dictionary via json.loads before calling run.sub so that
it uses dict substitution.
The second service, String Substitution, uses {{ get_var(payload_dict) }} as payload:
it is run.sub that will convert it from a string into the payload dictionary.

6e60fdc8-69f3-4309-8494-49d995f374ad.content:
Code of the temporal worker (PrintInput)

from asyncio import run
from datetime import timedelta

from temporalio import workflow, activity
from temporalio.client import Client
from temporalio.worker import Worker


@activity.defn
async def print_input(name):
    return f"Hi {name}!"

8361550c-5928-45e0-a38d-1f04d0110621.content:
Run a temporal Workflow called "Print Input".
Print Input takes a single argument: "name", and
it returns "Hi name!".

This workflow runs in DxD mode on two devices:
Washington and Austin.

The temporal service uses the following parameters:
Temporal Server URL: localhost:7233
Workflow Name: PrintInput
Task Queue: print-input-queue
Workflow Arguments: [device.name]

Since "device.name" is sent to the temporal worker,
the expected result should be:
"Hi, Washington!" and "Hi, Austin".

In the worker CLI, we should see:
"Workflow result: Hi, Washington!"
"Workflow result: Hi, Austin!"

In the temporal UI, there should be two workflows
marked as "Completed"

de7d460c-f709-4d07-95da-3bf14f613102.content:
@workflow.defn
class PrintInput:
    @workflow.run
    async def run(self, name):
        result = await workflow.execute_activity(
            print_input,
            name,
            start_to_close_timeout=timedelta(seconds=10),
        )
        print(f"Workflow result: {result}")
        return result

async def main():
    client = await Client.connect("localhost:7233")
    worker = Worker(
        client,
        task_queue="print-input-queue",
        workflows=[PrintInput],
        activities=[print_input],
    )
    await worker.run()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    run(main())

Run the command: "python print_input.py" to start the worker.
